item.title: The Council of Trent
item.description:
The Council of Trent, 1545-1563 (Pope Paul III)

defined the church doctrine -- examined the many theological questions raised by the Protestants and identified and explained where the Catholic Church stood on each issue,
required all priests to have a calling and an education able to read the bible
increased the church discipline to prevent corruption. religious courts and bring people up and evidence, and priest being defrocked punishments
the must have done something right -- after around 1550 the basic religious status of Europe remained unchanged. No more ground was lost to the protestants.

item.title: day 10 2
item.description:
The basic pattern: Luther started the Reformation in 1517. It took people
about 30 years to settle in and pick sides. Then over the next 100 years
they brutally tried to slaughter each other all over Europe. Thus the wars
of religion fall from roughly 1550-1650.
Why did they kill each other so savagely over religion?
Heaven and hell were literal places for them. Hell meant eternal
damnation and eternal torture. Real, physical torture. And there was only
one true path to God. So, by definition, if you weren’t on the path to God,
you were on the path to hell. Since the church you went to was obviously
the correct path, any other path was the Devil’s path.
A heretic was more dangerous than a murderer. A murderer might kill your
children – sad, yes, but then they go to God in heaven. A heretic threatens
their immortal soul.
THey are going to kill each other becuase they are sure that theirs is the correct one, and the concepts of heaven and hell are real for them, as that is there reward then hell is afoul, dante dipicts hell, demons draging people to hell, so you have to make sure your on the right path, and the other sides path is the devils path, if your not working wtih god your with the devil, and luthern said to kill the peasant, against the church a heritict, and a murder could snatch up your kid and kill him so he goes to heaven but a heritic could send them to hell. and what is going to heappen when we die, idea of deavil and demons is a real thing in their minds. the Ideas of demons being around cus they dont under stand science, black cats are the devil hard to see in the dark,

Dutch Revolt Against Spain 1566-1588 (officially 1648)
French Civil War, 1562-1598
(War of the 3 Henrys)
Thirty Years War, 1618-1648
(In a later chapter)
netherlands is controled by spain,

The Spanish Habsburgs ruled the Netherlands.
The Habsburgs were (very!) Catholic and wanted to
force the protestant (Calvinist) people of the
Netherlands back into the Catholic Church.
The Dutch rebelled against the harsh methods used –
including the Inquisition.
The British under Elizabeth I offered some assistance
which lead to the invasion of the Spanish Armada.
(1588)
Shockingly, England defeated the Armada. Spain will
not be able to threaten England or the Netherlands
again.
Functionally the northern part of the Netherlands was
independent after 1588, but it wasn’t formally
recognized until the end of the Thirty Years War in
1648.
At the time of the Armada, Spain
controlled the southern half of the
Netherlands, which they kept – it

and warlocks.

200,000 people were tried and 40-60,000 executed.
Most were single, old women

One arrest often lead to panics that created a wave of arrests.
(Salem Witch Trials in America, for example.)

popular in the Enlightenment – the 18th century.

item.guid: 10th graade/AP EURO/AP eupo/Chapter 17/Link it up/Blood Sports.md

item.title: Community Controls
item.description: "Community controls refer to the social mechanisms within a community that regulate and influence individuals' behavior, particularly regarding moral conduct, social roles, and power dynamics. These controls were enforced through societal expectations, informal sanctions, and public opinion. The community often had a direct influence on the lives of individuals, including marriage, family life, and social behavior, especially in rural and small-town settings during the early modern period. The community's influence over individual actions helped maintain social order and cohesion." - not mine
item.guid: 10th graade/AP EURO/AP eupo/Chapter 17/Link it up/Community Controls.md

item.title: Consumer Society
item.description: "Definition: A consumer society refers to a social order where the acquisition of goods and services plays a central role in individuals' lives and identities. During the 18th and 19th centuries, the rise of consumerism was closely tied to the growth of the middle class, increased urbanization, and the expansion of global trade. People began spending more time and resources buying goods, which were often seen as symbols of status and identity. Consumerism led to the development of new markets, advertising, and a shift in social values towards materialism and consumption." -notmine
item.guid: 10th graade/AP EURO/AP eupo/Chapter 17/Link it up/Consumer Society.md

item.guid: 10th graade/AP EURO/AP eupo/Chapter 17/Link it up/Crop Rotation.md

item.title: Edward Jenner
item.description: "Definition: Edward Jenner was an English physician and scientist who is credited with developing the first successful smallpox vaccine in 1796. Jenner observed that milkmaids who had contracted cowpox did not get smallpox, leading him to hypothesize that exposure to cowpox could protect against smallpox. He tested this idea by inoculating a young boy with cowpox and later exposing him to smallpox, finding that the boy did not develop the disease. Jenner's work laid the foundation for modern immunology and the development of vaccines." not mine
item.guid: 10th graade/AP EURO/AP eupo/Chapter 17/Link it up/Edward Jenner.md

item.guid: 10th graade/AP EURO/AP eupo/Chapter 17/Link it up/ENCLOSURE MOVEMENT.md

item.title: Illegitimacy Explosion
item.description: "Definition: The "illegitimacy explosion" refers to a significant rise in the number of children born out of wedlock, particularly during the 17th and 18th centuries in Europe. This was marked by a notable increase in illegitimate births, a trend that became evident with changing social norms, such as greater sexual freedom, economic conditions, and social mobility. The illegitimacy explosion challenged traditional family structures and raised questions about social morality and the role of the state in regulating family life." -- still not mine
item.guid: 10th graade/AP EURO/AP eupo/Chapter 17/Link it up/Illegitimacy Explosion.md

item.title: Infanticide
item.description: "Definition: Infanticide refers to the act of killing an infant, typically due to factors such as poverty, social stigma, or the inability to care for a child. During the early modern period, many infants, especially those born out of wedlock or to impoverished families, faced a high risk of death by neglect or deliberate killing. Infanticide was often seen as a desperate measure taken by mothers who lacked the means to raise a child in an unforgiving society." -- NOT MINE

item.title: Just Price
item.description: "Definition: The "just price" concept was a medieval and early modern idea that certain goods and services should be sold at a fair price based on the cost of production, basic needs, and moral considerations. It was believed that prices should not be excessively high or low and that traders should not exploit consumers. The just price was often associated with ideas of fairness, economic morality, and community welfare, particularly in the context of regulating markets and preventing exploitation." -- not mine
item.guid: 10th graade/AP EURO/AP eupo/Chapter 17/Link it up/Just Price.md

item.title: Methodists
item.description: "Definition: The Methodists were followers of the religious movement started by John Wesley in the 18th century. The movement emphasized personal piety, moral living, and the importance of regular prayer and Bible study. It was a reaction against what Wesley saw as the declining spirituality of the Church of England. The Methodists were known for their methodical approach to religious practice (hence the name) and for their focus on social reform, including advocating for the poor and marginalized. The movement eventually grew into a major Protestant denomination, the Methodist Church."

item.title: Open field system
item.description:
The open field system was a system in which a community of a village would have a shared land, which they would harvest and decide on the crops.
Divided in several large fields, which were in turn cut up into long, narrow strips.
The strips were had not been enclosed into small plots, still being open to anyone or thing.
The whole village followed a pattern of plowing, sowing, and harvesting in accordance with the traditions that have been around for a long time.
What was the reason behind using this system? The reason behind this system was to give a full community effort. Where in this case everyone would work to gather as a sorta hive mind.
What was a major deficiency of this system? item.title: Spare the rod and spoil the child
item.description: "Definition: This phrase is an old proverb advocating for the use of corporal punishment as a way to discipline children. The idea behind it is that children should be physically punished or disciplined (using the metaphor of the "rod") to teach them proper behavior. In the context of the 18th century, it reflected the prevailing belief in strict, authoritarian child-rearing practices, which were seen as necessary to maintain order and instill respect for authority." -- someones

item.title: Page 1
item.description:
Watch AP Euro Bit-by-Bit #23 (and the first 7:30 of Crash Course #8) and answer the following questions (Ch 17 pages 494-503)
NOTE: Up to this moment, we have really been focusing on many of the major political, religious, and economic developments that were occurring in Europe beginning with the rise of the Renaissance in the early 1400s, the development of multiple Christian denominations during the 1500s, and all culminating in the development of absolutism throughout much of Europe by the early 1700s. However, while these events and movements did significantly impact the over-all course of Europe’s development on a continental scale, for the vast number of Europeans living during this time period, the day-to-day life experiences from generation to generation did not change all that drastically. Remember, although influential, the middle class by no means was a true representation of Europe’s population as a whole. By the late 1600s, at least 80% of the Western European population still relied on agriculture as their primary livelihood and this number was certainly higher in the kingdoms of Eastern Europe.

1.Describe the purpose of the Open-field system of agriculture. GoTo Open field system Open field system

The open field system was a system in which a community of a village would have a shared land, which they would harvest and decide on the crops.
Divided in several large fields, which were in turn cut up into long, narrow strips.
The strips were had not been enclosed into small plots, still being open to anyone or thing.
The whole village followed a pattern of plowing, sowing, and harvesting in accordance with the traditions that have been around for a long time.
What was the reason behind using this system? The reason behind this system was to give a full community effort. Where in this case everyone would work to gather as a sorta hive mind.
What was a major deficiency of this system? This system was deficient when it came to innovation because if someone wanted to try crop rotation for the first time everyone would have to come to a consensus and that made it really difficult because not everyone would be willing to do that because it wasn't a long standing tradition.
NOTE: During the 1700s, England and the Netherlands led, what historians now refer to as, an Agricultural Revolution. Drawing upon the ideas of the Scientific Revolution, these countries worked towards improving agricultural output, making use of a variety of new technology, methods, and access to new foods.
2. One of the major innovations during the Agricultural Revolution was the use of crop rotation. What is Crop Rotation and why was it an improvement over the open field system? Crop Rotation Crop Rotation

Crop Rotation is like the name implies the rotation of crops to allow for the fields to be replenished, this would lead to the end of the one thirds field system as crop rotation would allow for crops to be replenished
It is an improvement over the open field system as the open field system would be a consensus with the community so change would be hard so it would still be the continuation of the one thirds field system so it would also then give nuitreinst to the soil and crops.
2a. How did it also impact livestock (and thus ultimately people’s diets)? This would give more food for the live stock as there would be more food for the people. So it would impact their diet by giving more protein / nutrients into their diet.
3. How did the Columbian Exchange ultimately impact the Agricultural Revolution in Europe? The Columbian Exchange impacted the Agricultural Revolution in Europe by giving rise to crop rotation which came about due to the enclosure movement and that collimated to give a better diet. And crop rotation could come about due to the New Crops coming from the Columbain Exchange.
3a. According to John Greene (Crash Course), why is the potato the world’s most important plant of the last 500 years? day 12 12 crash course number 8 << notes on video
John Greene stated that the potato didn't need great soil. So with that they could be planted pretty much anywhere and they would grow.
4. In what sense did Jethro Tull’s seed drill represent not only a mechanical but also a scientific agricultural improvement? Jethro Tull's seed drill represent a mechanical improvement because it was the yield improvement in the field for the seed were planted into the soil which then would allow them to germinate better which is the scientific advanment.


5. What was the enclosure movement and how did it represent a more scientific approach to agriculture? The enclosure movement was
ENCLOSURE MOVEMENT ENCLOSURE MOVEMENT

The enclouse movemnt was a movemnet in which large land owners would buy out or take the land of the peaseants and enclose it with something like fences,
Nobles also would take thier land share and enclose it off,
this would kick out peasants farmers with led to the decline of population in rural community's and this would lead to ppl needing work so they could survive. And this would also lead to the Cottage Industry.
it represented the ability for more land to be used for experiments like the new idea of crop rotation.
5a. How did it impact the land owners? First the peasant farmers were forced to sell their land because they could not longer use the commons. So they would have to die, more to town to find work or start work in the cottage industry
Second would be the gentlemen farmer which they would buy the land that the peasant farmers left and would begin to stuff to make money.
5b. How did it impact the peasant farmers?
Forced to sell their land
Find new work or starve.
Brain Challenge #1:  Who benefits?
The agricultural revolution had a significantly different impact on the rich and the poor. How a person felt about the developments might well depend on their social status

How did the agricultural revolution impact wealthy landowners?
The ag revolution impacted the wealthy landowners by allowing them to experiment and they could purchase more land.
How did the agricultural revolution impact poor farmers?
The Ag. revolution impacted the poor farmers leading them to leave, starve to death, or work in the putting out industry. 
Given both its short and long-term impacts, was the agricultural revolution a good thing?
The short term impacts were wealthy landowners were they would make more money while at the misery of the poor farmers who had to find another way to survive or die. 
The long term impacts would be the mass production of food that would be provided, giving rise to putting out industry.
Overall the agricultural revolution was a good thing because the consequences outweigh the actions that affected the poor farmers because people have more food so less people will die of starvation.
6. In a nutshell, what were the major impacts of the agricultural revolution on European society (especially the British and the Dutch)? Be sure to give a brief description of each impact.
Healthier life more nutrients in food,
More land for the Dutch becasue they got rid of the low land waters
More food from the use of crop rotation
Encolusre movement which drove peasant farmers to work in a town or in the cttage industy


NOTE: As shown by the previous section, the agricultural revolution during the late 17 th and early 18 th centuries had a dramatic impact on society. That said, it must be noted that these impacts varied from region to region depending on things such as how aggressive countries were in implementing these new techniques and ideas as well as what political system was in use at the time (think Eastern vs Western absolutism as well as absolutism vs constitutional systems). With that in mind, these movements eventually led to what is now referred to as the industrious revolution (not to be confused with the industrial revolution). Watch AP Euro Bit-by-Bit #24 and answer the following questions (Ch 17 pages 503-508)
7. Since the Middle Ages, many businesses had operated under the Guild system. In general, what was a Guild? A guild was like a govermental deparment but it had nothing to due with the goverment,
7a. What were the benefits of the guild system? They would train workers, they had fixed prices for what was sold, they gave fair wages, and regulated waht was sold
7b. What were some disadvantages of the guild system? The guild system would curb inovation into new tech that wouldn't be work done by man. And they would run you out of town if you were not affiliated with the guild.
8. Describe the putting-out system. How did it work? The beginning of the putting out system was were a wealthy business owner would give raw products to a worker and they would make a quota and they would get a wage, then later in the putting out system workers would become speiclized, they also didn't own the object that were made. that being uselly textiles.
Brain Challenge #2: Urban vs. Rural
In modern America we usually associated the manufacturing of goods with large urban factories,
yet the first significant production of for-market production took place in rural areas. (Cottage
industry and the putting out system.) In the early modern era what were the advantages or
disadvantages offered by each of the following locations:

Urban Areas:       
Infrastructure for transportation was a lot better in urban areas because of the greater development in their economy.
Guilds regulated skilled labor, so being able to hire them.
Rural Areas:
There was poor infrastructure which could hinder the transportation of materials and products. 
Guilds didn’t regulation so there is a lack of skilled labor.
9. What was the reason for the development of what became known as the putting-out system (or Cottage industry)? The formation of colonies that did not have the mean to produce the textiles
9a. Why was this advantageous for entrepreneurs? Because they could make a lot of money
9b. Why was this advantageous for farm laborers? They may make more money


10. When compared with cottage industries, list and give a description of 2 advantages of the guild system.
Standerided wages
Better work safety/ workers comp.
NOTE: As you have hopefully realized, both the agricultural revolution and the industrious revolution (including the putting out system) resulted, not only from the implementation of ideas stemming from the Scientific Revolution, but also from the age of exploration (including the colonization of the New World along and expanded trade with Africa and Asia). Pages 634-647in the textbook serve as a good review of this material. Watch the Enlightenment Thinkers video (4:25-10:30) AND read the textbook pages 508--514, then answer the following questions
11. What were the main ideas behind the economic theory of mercantilism? Gain more gold from exports and don't lose gold due to imports
11a. In this system (mercantilism), what was the role of the government? The role of the government would be the main regulator and controler it wasn't as laissez-faire
NOTE: Whereas many Enlightenment ideas such as freedom of speech and religious belief conflicted with restrictions resulting from stringent political systems such as absolutism, the ideas of Adam Smith focused more on problems stemming from the absolutist economic theory of the time: Mercantilism. His book, Inquiry into the Nature and Causes of the Wealth of Nations (1776) established the basis for modern economics.
12. How did the Enlightenment idea of selfishness and the individual play a role in Adam Smith’s economic theory? It would tie into a laissez-faire system where individuals of a society would control the market a free market, as they would have control they could decided what they do as they see fit.
12a. According to Smith, what is the Invisible Hand? (why is it invisible?) Basicly the forces that control the market, no one can really predict what the market will do.
12b. How is this theory a reaction to Mercantilism? Because Mercantilism was administered by the government a gave little choice to private individuals, thus people should control the market not the government.
12c. Given your answers to the above questions, why would the notion of competition (free market) be so vital to Smith’s ideas? Because it would make companies have to innovate and have the best prices and best quality for them to stay in business, thus it being a moving force and being vital.
13. According to Adam Smith, what were the 3 duties a government should limit itself to?
natinal defense
administration of justice
public goods.


Brain Challenge #3: Would the creation of public schools fit under Smith’s umbrella of governmental
responsibilities? Why or why not?
The creation of public schools would fit under the umbrella of Smith’s governmental responsibilities because it could be considered as a public good. As the creation of schools is something that benefits the people and thus the economy, it would be natural to fit under Smith’s rules for a government.
The Changing Life of the People
Chapter 18
There will not be a typical reading guide for chapter 18. Instead you will need to use the basic information in creating your character sketch. There are, however, some vocabulary terms for the chapter. Define the following terms/phrases being sure to be thorough enough that your definitions are meaningful.

Just Price
goods be sold at the level of their quality to be fair and not exploit the consumer.
Consumer Society
consumerism, people spending time buying products
This is them identifying them self as that what they buy
Edward Jenner. What did he do?
He found that milkmaids didn't get small pox as badly and so made a vaccine that would help others.
Methodists
social reform and practice, using medicine, to live a more pious life. Started in england
Blood Sports
Blood Sports

This is violent entertainment, so like cock fighting, or the gladiator battles, so bull-baiting, and bear-baiting. So they would then torture the animals to their death. Which was a way to show the dominance humans had over animals, such as the lower class leisure activities. Brain Challenge #1
Part A: Given your responses to the preceding questions (1 & 2), why did the idea that a societal revolution was imminent make sense?
The idea that a societal revolution makes sense is because the proletariat in france were ‘slaves’ to the bourgeoisie. The proletariat were starving on the streets while the estates above 1 and 2 made Enlightenment ideas such as liberty, equality and freedom. But nonetheless who cares for the 3 estate peoples starving on the streets. And the bubble exploded leading to revolution upon the class system. Thus the idea that a societal revolution being imminent makes sense as people were ready to oppose oppression and be given the right to live.
Part B: Given your responses to the preceding questions (1 & 2), why might a revolution during the late 18th and/or early 19th century become socially divisive? 
A revolution during the late 18th and/or early 19th century would become socially divisive because Liberty didn’t mean equality. Women would not have the same rights as man. Racism present wouldn’t playing too much. And a believe that economic equality shouldn’t exist. This would greatly impact many groups and thus leading to a socially divisive revolution.

item.title: Neg
item.description:
Value: government legitimacy
Criterion: categorical imperative
main idea is that the ICC and Law of the Sea are treaties and there is no governing body which goes against the coercion of a person and treating the people the the united states a means to an end.
And that this has no rights over the people of the United states.

Yoo and Stradner 20 [John Yoo, Emanuel S. Heller Professor of Law at the UC Berkeley School of Law, Visiting Fellow at the Hoover Institution at Stanford, and Visiting Scholar at the American Enterprise Institute, and Ivana Stradner, research fellow at the Foundation for Defense of Democracies, 3-17-2020, "The U.S. Must Reject the International Criminal Court’s Attack on Its National Sovereignty", National Review, https://www.nationalreview.com/2020/03/united-states-must-reject-international-criminal-court-attack-on-national-sovereignty/\]/Kankee
Last week, the International Criminal Court (ICC) authorized an investigation of alleged war crimes and crimes against humanity by U.S., Afghan, and Taliban troops in Afghanistan, as well as by CIA black sites operated in Poland, Lithuania, and Romania. While the prosecution will likely fail, it represents another effort by a global elite — consisting of European governments, international organizations, and their supporting interest groups, academics, and activists — to threaten American sovereignty. The Rome Statute, which established the ICC in 1998, was supported by 120 states. It had the worthy goal of preventing the world’s most horrific crimes. Today the ICC can exercise jurisdiction over war crimes, crimes against humanity, aggression, and genocide. Its founders believed that an international organization in the form of a court could replace the customary role of nation-states to punish those who violate the rules of civilized warfare. The Clinton administration signed the treaty in 2000, but did not submit it for Senate ratification. American support for the court dissolved after 9/11, as American officials worried that the ICC would become an anti-American kangaroo court used by certain countries to constrain nation-state sovereignty. In 2002, the Bush administration announced that it would not sign the agreement, and empowered then-State Department official John Bolton to lead a U.S. campaign to sign bilateral immunity agreements with more than 100 countries to protect both parties from the ICC’s jurisdiction. Ever since, the ICC has labored ineffectually. To date, the Court has spent more than $2 billion dollars and yielded just eight successful convictions and four acquittals, focusing only on African countries. While there are 123 member states, nations that still might have to wage war, such as the U.S., Israel, India, South Korea, China, and Russia, have refused to join. America’s Western European allies, perhaps still hoping for a utopian future where war has disappeared and meager conventional forces are all that is needed, lend the ICC its greatest support. Most ICC officials have long hoped to achieve international relevance by attacking the ICC’s greatest critic: the United States. Since November 2017, ICC chief prosecutor Fatou Bensouda has sought to use alleged crimes in Afghanistan to bring charges against the U.S. military and intelligence community. America’s response has been tough, and after numerous threats by the ICC, U.S. secretary of state Mike Pompeo ordered the revocation of the ICC chief prosecutor’s U.S. entry visa (though Bensouda managed to circumvent the ban and attend her UN meetings last April). The ICC Pre-Trial Chamber later ruled against an investigation (and possible prosecution) of the U.S. for alleged crimes in Afghanistan because both would most likely fail. Last week, however, the ICC’s appellate court reversed this finding and allowed Bensouda to continue her pursuits of American activities in Afghanistan and elsewhere after 9/11. To end this charade, the U.S. should continue to challenge the Court’s jurisdiction and protect the rights of nations that are bound only by rules to which they consent. The Trump administration should continue to deny ICC officials and any government officials (such as any military or law enforcement officers) that assist them from entering the United States or using its financial system. Most important, the United States should strike at the ICC through its supporters. Japan, the United Kingdom, France, Italy, Canada, Spain, Mexico, and Australia are all major Court funders. The Trump administration should warn countries who are ICC top funders yet depend utterly on the U.S. for their defense (such as Japan) that they cannot expect American troops to protect any nation seeking to prosecute and imprison them. It should weaken defense ties with ICC member countries, and cut foreign aid to any nation that cooperates with the Court. With these actions, the Trump administration will defend the rights, not just of the United States, but of all sovereign nations. America did not join the Rome Statute. It remains unfettered by its requirements. To protect international law, it should refuse to recognize any ICC probe. International rules should only bind nations that consent to them. Allowing the ICC to claim power over the U.S., which does not consent to its jurisdiction will erode any incentive to obey any international rules at all. The ICC’s actions threaten the only true mechanism for deterring human rights abuses. Subjecting U.S. forces to an after-the-fact and idealistic human-rights barometer will only discourage Washington from intervening to end massive human-rights abuses in difficult world hotspots. If the global elite want the U.S. to lead efforts to end killings in places such as Syria, Yemen, or Sudan, the last thing it should do is prosecute American troops when they take on the difficult jobs that no other nation can or will do.

item.title: Trickle up over trickle down when taxed
item.description:
https://academic.oup.com/oxrep/article/39/3/399/7245707
rates, and tax incentives for investment and innovation. The body of literature offers some lessons, although increasing availability of administrative data should shed further light on these issues: workers bear some of the burden of taxes on the rich, but the extent of such incidence depends on heterogeneity across workers as well as labour and product market characteristics. The largest part of the burden of corporation tax is likely shared by business owners and workers at the higher end of the income distribution. There is limited evidence of any trickle-down effects and, if anything, evidence is stronger for ‘trickle-up’ from benefits to low-income individuals (Zidar, 2019).

item.title: A Peek into Creon’s Cursed State of Mind
item.description:
Logan M. Otremba
Ms. Luond
Honors English 2
15 December 2024
A Peek into Creon’s Cursed State of Mind
After it is found that Antigone’s brother has been given a proper burial, Creon sends his guards to find the perpetrator and investigate this matter. In which Creon has time to ponder the punishment for the perpetrator.
My guards better find this insolent human that has committed such a deed which goes against my very command of this city. I’ll personally dispatch brutality upon this wretched criminal by my own unforgiving hands. They shall feel coursing throughout their body the concentrated power of ten thousand suns'. As I will poison them by giving them just a bare nonlethal dose of hemlock. Just enough so it’s as if they were to meet the same fate of the late Socrates.
So let the lands tremble in my wake for the torture that will unfurl. Their cries will howl in the bright night. Then I’ll let them see with their bare eyes as I push a needle further and further under their nail. Then peeling off the nail to leave the skin festering in the elements. After which such dastardly tendrils shall be burned. I’ll take and place them on molten steel that yearns for the victim's blood. I then shall slide sharpened steel slowly strongly subjecting such surreal sensation, scaring the very depths of their soul.
Their blood-curdling screams will be The Music of the Night to which my ears have the pleasure of. I truly see it as a blessing in disguise with their folly being their gruesome demise. Such be the life of a criminal, that goes against my absolute laws of the land. For a fact, the Gods will be overjoyed once I’m through with this criminal. That should set things right as rightfully be when you make a wimp right out of me.

item.title: GErman book thing
item.description:
**

Your book should have at least 6 pages, with the following topics covered on each page:
Cover Page | Title

Mein Leben: Ein Buch über mich!

Seite 1 |  Introduction: Wer bin ich?

Introduce yourself (name, age, birthday, where you live).

Example: “Ich heiße Maria. Ich bin sechzehn Jahre alt und ich wohne in [your town].”

Seite 2 | Meine Hobbys und Interessen

Talk about your hobbies, favorite activities, or sports you play. Include why you enjoy them.

Example: “Ich spiele gerne Fußball, weil es spannend ist. Ich lese auch gern Bücher.”

Seite 3 | Meine Familie

Describe your family (how many people, who they are, what they do).

Example: “Ich habe eine kleine Familie. Meine Mutter heißt Anna und sie ist Lehrerin.”

Seite 4 | Ein typischer Tag für mich

Describe a typical day in your life, including what you do and when.

Example: “Ich stehe um 7 Uhr auf und gehe zur Schule. Nach der Schule mache ich Hausaufgaben.”

Seite 5 | Meine Lieblingssachen

Describe some of your favorite things (food, music, movies, places, etc.).

Example: “Mein Lieblingsessen ist Pizza. Ich höre gern Popmusik, besonders [artist/band].”

Seite 6 | Meine Träume und Pläne für die Zukunft

Talk about what you want to do in the future (dream job, places to visit, etc.).

Example: “In der Zukunft möchte ich nach Deutschland reisen.

Seite 7 | Meine Träume und Pläne für die Zukunft

Write a message thanking the reader for reading your book.

Danke, dass du mein Buch gelesen hast!


Use a mix of regular verbs, stem-changing verbs, and modal verbs (müssen, können, wollen, etc.).

Each page should have at least 5 sentences.

Be sure to illustrate each page with drawings, photos, or digital images that match your descriptions.

Pay attention to vocabulary and try to use as many new words as possible.


Day 1 (Today): Introduction to the project, brainstorming ideas, and outlining the book.

Day 2: Start drafting your pages (Introduction & Hobbies/Interests).

Day 3: Work on Family & Typical Day pages.

Day 4: Work on Favorite Things & Future Plans pages.

Day 5: Finish drafts, review, and make revisions. Show book to Frau C if needed/wanted.

Day 6: Work on illustrations, finalize the book, and peer review.

Day 7 (Final Day): Turn in your completed book and present it to a small group in class.



Content: Did you cover all required topics and write at least 5 sentences per page?
Vocabulary: Did you use a variety of words, including some of the verbs and vocabulary we’ve reviewed?
Grammar: Did you attempt to use different verbs (regular, stem-changing, modal)? Mistakes are okay, but you should try!
Creativity: Is your book well-organized, colorful, and fun to read?
Effort: Did you spend time on your project and produce something thoughtful and complete?
**

Cover Page | Title
Mein Leben: Ein Buch über mich!
Ich bin mich!

Seite 1 |  Introduction: Wer bin ich?
Hallo, ich bin Logan M. Otremba und ich bin 16 Jahre alt und ich wohne in Fargo!
Ich habe Geburtstag ist das Fünftel auf September!
Ich anhabe rosa Gold Brille und habe Sonnenbrille!
Ich komme auf America im North Dakota!
Ich liebe zu lernen viele Dinge!

Seite 2 | Meine Hobbys und Interessen
Ich spiele Tennis aber es ende am erst Oktober!
Und ich liebe wissen-shale, es ist sehr Vergnügen!
Ich spiele Klavier es einfach order schwer zeitweise Kannen!
Und ich bin ein Programmierer im Python, JavaScript und mehr!
Auch ich spiele realistisch Minecraft, und ich verbringe viele Stunden!

Seite 3 | Meine Familie
Ich habe viele Familie. Miene Mutter ist Lehrerin für viele Jahre!
Mein Vater ist ein Programmierer für John Deere!
Und Ich habe zwei elder schwester, und zwei Hunde!
Meine Hunde heiße ist Sophie und Oliver, und Sophie ist Blind!
Oliver liebe seine laufen, er läuft am sechs Uhr morgen und siebzehn Uhr abends!

Seite 4 | Ein typischer Tag für mich
Ich spiele realistisch Minecraft am Wochenende manchmal!
Und mein Hausaufgabe gibt mich erdrückend Furcht!
Und dann Ich abarbeite Hausaufgabe darum!
Ich stehe um 6 Uhr auf und gehe zur Schule um 7 Uhr!
Und ich programmiere im Schule um 12 Urh manchmal!

Seite 5 | Meine Lieblingssachen
Mein Lieblingsessen ist Nicht Pizza, es ist schlect!
Ich höre gern Power-Metal, besonders DragonForce!
Ich höre gern Klavier, wann ich lese Bücher!
Mein Lieblingsvideospielen ist wahrscheinlich Minecraft!
Mein Lieblingsprogrammiersprache ist Python oder JavaScript!

Seite 6 | Meine Träume und Pläne für die Zukunft
In der Zukunft möchte ich nach Schweiz reisen!
Und im der hoch alpen!
In der Zukunft möchte ich nach Programmierer arbiten!
Im etwas Beispiel für Python order JavaScript!
In der Zukunft möchte ich esse Popcorn!

Radio waves, Electro Magnetic Radiation, this would be more wireless rather then connected like via ethernet,
Is this potentially dangerous? How?
could
Radio frequency of high level can cause thermal heating resulting in tissue damage. (fcc.gov)
couldn't
Radio frequency in low levels do not show bad effects. Fcc.gov
"To date, there is no consistent or credible scientific evidence of health problems caused by the exposure to radio frequency energy emitted by cell phones" (fda.gov)

item.title: things stuff
item.description:
In C#, you cannot directly invoke a managed DLL using rundll32.exe as rundll32.exe is meant for calling unmanaged DLLs. However, you can create a mixed-mode or native method within a DLL that rundll32.exe can call. Alternatively, you could write a console application in C# instead.
Here's a workaround with C# that simulates the approach by using a method to print "Hello World," but keep in mind this won't work with rundll32.exe directly because rundll32 expects unmanaged methods (like those written in C or C++).


Create a C# DLL Project
   Create a new C# class library project in Visual Studio or via the .NET CLI.
   ```bash
   dotnet new classlib -n HelloWorldDll
   ```

Write the Code
   Open the Class1.cs file and write the following code:
   ```csharp
   using System;
   using System.Runtime.InteropServices;
   public class HelloWorld
   {
       // This is the method that rundll32.exe expects to call
       [DllExport("Run", CallingConvention = CallingConvention.StdCall)]
       public static void Run(int hWnd, int hInst, string lpszCmdLine, int nCmdShow)
       {
           Console.WriteLine("Hello World");
       }
   }
   // Custom attribute to handle exporting the method as unmanaged
   [AttributeUsage(AttributeTargets.Method)]
   public class DllExportAttribute : Attribute
   {
       public DllExportAttribute(string exportName, CallingConvention callingConvention) {}
   }
   ```

Install the UnmanagedExports NuGet Package
   To export a method from the managed DLL that can be called by rundll32.exe, you need to use the DllExport attribute, which is available via some third-party libraries such as UnmanagedExports.
   Install the package:
   ```bash
   Install-Package UnmanagedExports -Version 1.2.7
   ```

Build the Project
   After writing the code, compile the DLL:
   ```bash
   dotnet build
   ```

Call the DLL with rundll32.exe
   Now, you should be able to call the DLL via rundll32.exe:
   ```bash
   rundll32.exe HelloWorldDll.dll,Run
   ```


The DllExport attribute is used to export the method so it can be called via rundll32.exe.
The method Run is the entry point that rundll32.exe expects to call, and it prints "Hello World" to the console.
You must use CallingConvention.StdCall because rundll32.exe expects methods with this calling convention.
Note: This is not a typical use case for C# and managed code. Normally, rundll32.exe is used for invoking unmanaged DLL functions, so this workaround leverages external libraries to handle method exports in a managed environment.
**
